name: American Kestrel
overview: Small bird with blue and orange-brown heads and distinct black markings below eyes. Males feature blue wings, brown-black backs, and rusty red tails. Females have orange-brown backs and wings as well as black barring on their tails.
behavior: Often seen perched on tall structures or hovering over fields while hunting. Commonly seen flapping tails for balance. Makes a klee-klee-klee call when threatened. They mostly eat insects but are generally opportunistic. Does not discriminate in diet.
habitat: American Kestrels are generally solitary in grasslands, deserts, cities, and suburbs. Kestrel boxes are installed around the reserve. They tend to occupy and nest in cavities of trees and buildings.
size: 8.7 to 12.2 inches and a wingspan of 20â€“24 inches
